entry.title: Gazprom to sell Armenian hotel, CivilNet investigation finds: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Gazprom to sell Armenian hotel, CivilNet investigation finds: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan‚Äôs cabinet put forward a budget proposal for next year that envisages Armenia‚Äôs economy to expand by 5.6%. The government plans total revenues to approach $7.5 billion, while expenditures are expected to top $9 billion. üìç Babken Tunyan, a leading pro-government lawmaker, dismissed speculation that the government is, apparently, considering nationalizing the country‚Äôs main electric utility. üìç The United Kingdom-based company that owns Vorotan, Armenia‚Äôs largest hydroelectric power plant, plans to invest an additional $14.4 million in the facility through 2026. üìç The Armenian subsidiary of Gazprom, the Russian state-owned energy giant, is trying to sell off a hotel it owns in the resort town of Tsaghkadzor, a CivilNet investigation found.

entry.title: Pashinyan‚Äôs cabinet proposes to boost military budget

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan‚Äôs cabinet proposes to boost military budget
media:group.media:description:
üìç New York City Mayor Eric Adams allegedly took bribes from the Turkish government in exchange for not making a statement on the Armenian Genocide and for using his power to fast-track the construction of a Turkish consulate in the city. üìç Nikol Pashinyan, spoke yesterday at this year‚Äôs United Nations General Assembly, reiterating that the Armenian Constitution has no territorial claims toward Azerbaijan and stressing that the two countries are close to signing a normalization deal. üìç Armenia plans on increasing its military budget by 20% next year, up to roughly $1.73 billion, according to the budget proposal approved by the country‚Äôs cabinet yesterday. üìç Insights with Eric Hacopian: https://youtu.be/prIEcFg7G9Q?si=R_IW7E9cVJPafUXR

entry.title: What can be done to halt the Armenian cultural destruction in Artsakh

media:group.media:title: What can be done to halt the Armenian cultural destruction in Artsakh
media:group.media:description:
It has been exactly one year since the forced migration of Armenians from Artsakh. Since then, Azerbaijan has begun to swiftly erase Armenian cultural heritage from the region. Experts warn that if this cultural destruction is not stopped, all traces of Armenian presence in Artsakh will disappear over time. What is the international community doing to address this? What steps are being taken by the Republic of Armenia? What solutions are available, and what are the consequences of inaction?

media:group.media:title: Decoding the prime minister‚Äôs comments
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of Insights, host Eric Hacopian delves into Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan's pivotal speech at the Global Armenian Summit, offering a critical analysis of its implications for Armenia's future. Eric unpacks the prime minister's key points and their potential impact on Armenia's domestic and foreign policies in the post-Artsakh conflict era.
